nodes.bodyText:
Who will use this?

If it's an end-user, what's the use case?
If it's for us, to do InitializedTrend magic later, I 'd rather not expose it in the public API (especially because there's no POC of the InitializedTrend magic (for which there is no bandwidth now)). Otherwise we BC promise it.

In the second case, we can put it in an AbstractConstraint or InnerConstraint class (a new class between Constraint and Drools/BavetConstraint). Wdyt?
Both BavetConstraint and DroolsConstraint get a shared superclass, to get some code reuse in there.

This is changing the javadocs to the implementation reality (of CS-D), today.
We should investigate the work for the reverse: change the implementation reality to adhere to the javadocs :)
In theory, it's matter of deactiving rules if the constraintWeight is zero. We should reopen that discussion with Mario for Rule.setEnabled(false).

Since there isn't any compilation (we're doing straight executable model), it shouldn't be too slow.

nodes.bodyText:
Soft suggestion:
I'd use the word "instead" in these sentences for clarity.
Also "you intend to mix positive and negative weights" could be interpreted in general, not just for this constraint. We really want to discourage them using "impact".
Suggestion:
"... unless you intend to mix positive and negative weights"
-> "... instead, unless this constraint can both have positive and negative weights."
Also, I 'd always put it as the second paragraph, as I think this nudging (yes that's what it is :)), is more important what getConstraintPackage() etc default to.
